content:
• Monday, November 26, 2018
  • SAVE

    Spirit Airlines soars 10% on Q4 guidance

    • Spirit Airlines (NASDAQ:SAVE) +10% after-hours as it forecasts Q4 total revenue per available seat mile to rise ~11% Y/Y, compared to its initial estimate of a 6% gain, citing higher non-ticket revenue and higher load factor expectations.
    • SAVE says its initiatives to "dynamically price non-ticket items such as seats, bags and bundled service offerings have ramped faster than expected, driving non-ticket revenue."
    • The company also modestly improves its range for Q4 cost per available seat mile excluding fuel, estimating 5%-5.5% Y/Y increase.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:56 PM | 27 Comments
  • UTX

    United Technologies confirms split into three companies

    • United Technologies (NYSE:UTX) confirms on its call that it will separate into three independent companies with the completion of the Rockwell Collins (NYSE:COL) deal.
    • The company had been pushed by both Bill Ackman and Dan Loeb to think about breaking into stand-alones for its aerospace, climate-control and elevator units.
    • That suggests execs indeed were leaning toward breaking up the company as soon as it closed the deal.
    • United was already likely to sell assets like its fire, safety and security business as it looked to cut debt.
    • UTX is up 1.6% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:54 PM | 71 Comments
  • SAVE

    JinkoSolar, Halozyme and Amarin among after hour movers

    • Gainers: SAVE +13.8%. FTNW +8.4%. JKS +2.4%. VSI +1.9%. PCG +1.5%.
    • Losers: GSM -26.6%. GTHX -12.3%. HALO -10.2%. AMRN -5.9%. KOS -5.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • ADUS

    ADUS, LW, MXIM, FANG, PEB moving on S&P index changes

    • Addus HomeCare (NASDAQ:ADUS) is up 2.9% in late trading on news of moving into the S&P SmallCap 600.
    • It's replacing CACI International (NYSE:CACI), which is moving up to the MidCap 400, where it will replace Lamb Weston Holdings (NYSE:LW). And Lamb Weston is joining the S&P 500 to replace Rockwell Collins (NYSE:COL), set to be acquired tonight by United Technologies. LW is down 1.7% after hours.
    • In other moves, Maxim Integrated Products (NASDAQ:MXIM) is replacing Aetna (NYSE:AET) in the S&P 500, with CVS set to close on its deal for Aetna. MXIM is up 4.6% after hours.
    • Diamondback Energy (NASDAQ:FANG) is moving to the S&P 500 to replace Stericycle (NASDAQ:SRCL), which is moving down to replace Energen (NYSE:EGN) in the MidCap 400, as Diamondback is set to acquire Energen. FANG is up 1.5% after hours.
    • And lastly, with Pebblebrook Hotel Trust's (NYSE:PEB) deal for LaSalle Hotel Properties (NYSE:LHO) nearing closure, Pebblebrook will replace LaSalle in the MidCap 400. PEB is up 2% after hours.
    • All moves are effective prior to next Monday's open, Dec. 3.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 1 Comment
  • SABR

    Sabre -1.6% as TPG, Silver Lake plan to sell holdings

    • Sabre (NASDAQ:SABR) is 1.6% lower after hours after announcing a secondary offering of about 23.4M shares for selling stockholders.
    • The company's not selling any of the shares.
    • The sell-off of 23,386,376 shares represents the entire holdings of the shareholders affiliated with TPG Global and Silver Lake.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM
  • LOXO

    FDA OKs Loxo's Vitrakvi

    • The FDA approves Loxo Oncology's (NASDAQ:LOXO) VITRAKVI (larotrectinib) for the treatment of NTRK fusion-positive solid tumors.
    • Shares are currently halted.
    • Previously: FDA accepts Loxo's marketing application for larotrectinib for NTRK fusion cancers, action date November 26 (May 29)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:10 PM | 9 Comments
  • BMY

    Bristol-Myers Squibb's Opdivo + Yervoy flunks late-stage lung cancer study; shares off 3% after hours

    • Bristol-Myers Squibb (NYSE:BMY) is down 3% after hours on the heels of its announcement that a Phase 3 clinical trial, CheckMate-451, evaluating Opdivo (nivolumab) plus low-dose Yervoy (ipilimumab) as maintenance therapy in patients with extensive-stage small cell lung cancer without disease progression after the completion of first-line chemo failed to achieve the primary endpoint of overall survival (OS) compared to placebo.
    • The company plans to work with the investigators on publishing the results.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:00 PM | 6 Comments
  • BKE

    Buckle -6% after earnings miss

    • Buckle (NYSE:BKE) is down 6.2% after Q3 results miss estimates.
    • Comparable sales fell 1.4% during the quarter.
    • Net income was $20.5M vs. $19.9M a year ago.
    • Previously: Buckle misses by $0.04, misses on revenue (Nov. 26)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:45 PM
  • IMGN

    ImmunoGen finance chief bids adieu; shares up 3% after hours

    • ImmunoGen (NASDAQ:IMGN) announces the immediate departure of CFO David Johnston. A search is underway for a successor.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:43 PM | 4 Comments
  • AMRN

    Amarin readies equity offering; shares down 7% after hours

    • Amarin (NASDAQ:AMRN) launches a public offering of American Depositary Shares (ADSs). Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced.
    • Shares are down 7% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM | 29 Comments
  • Z

    Zillow Group strong after director buys nearly $25M worth

    • Zillow Group outpaced a strong market today (Z +11.9%, ZG +11.8%) following a disclosure from boardmember Jay Hoag that he bought 850,000 shares last week.
    • Those purchases came at prices between $29.087/share (650,000 shares) and $29.4736/share (200,000 shares).
    • His position after the transactions came to about 2.79M shares.
    • Shares in Z landed at $32.89 at the close, and ZG at $32.57.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM | 6 Comments
  • ACAD

    Acadia Pharma files for shelf stock offering; shares down 7% after hours

    • ACADIA Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ACAD) slips 7% after hours in reaction to its prospectus for an unspecified shelf stock offering.
    • Update: In a press release, the company specifies a $200M offering of common stock.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:37 PM | 7 Comments
  • FRAN

    Francesca's -10% after preliminary results disappoint

    • Shares of Francesca's (NASDAQ:FRAN) fall sharply after the retailer's preliminary Q3 results arrive short of estimates.
    • Francesca's expects Q3 EPS of -$0.19 to -$0.17 vs. -$0.03 consensus.
    • Sales decreased 10% during the quarter to $95M vs. $106M consensus after comparable sales fell off 14%.
    • CEO update: "It is clearly taking longer than we anticipated to achieve an inflection point in the business as we saw continued softness in traffic trends during third quarter and did not deliver the improved performance we had anticipated. We believe that the steps we are taking in resetting our merchandising strategy, enhancing our marketing approach, investing in our omni-channel and reformatting our boutiques to better showcase our product will ultimately drive improved sales and profitability."
    • FRAN -9.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM | 9 Comments
  • GTHX

    G1 Therapeutics' trilaciclib preserves immune system function in mid-stage lung cancer study

    • Topline results from a Phase 2 clinical trial evaluating G1 Therapeutics' (NASDAQ:GTHX) trilaciclib, combined with chemo and Roche's (OTCQX:RHHBY) Tecentriq (atezolizumab), for the first-line treatment of patients with small cell lung cancer showed a treatment benefit in terms of preserving immune system function compared to placebo + chemo/Tecentriq. Patients receiving the triplet therapy experienced less neutropenia, anemia and thrombocytopenia compared to the placebo group.
    • There was no statistical difference between trilaciclib and placebo in terms of overall response rate, median duration of response or median progression-free survival, however.
    • The company plans to review the "totality" of the data with regulatory authorities next quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM | 5 Comments
  • AAPL

    Apple -1.6% as Trump hints at boosted phone/laptop tariffs on China

    • Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is the latest company to get a "Trump dip," as President Trump suggests consumers could handle a tariff put on iPhones and laptops imported from China.
    • "Maybe. Maybe. Depends on what the rate is," Trump tells the WSJ. “I mean, I can make it 10%, and people could stand that very easily.”
    • AAPL is down 1.6% postmarket.
    • Trump was signaling a potential boost to tariffs ahead of talks coming later in the week -- raises of levels on $200B of Chinese goods to 25%.
    • Trump's word to companies building in China and exporting to U.S.: “What I’d advise is for them to build factories in the United States and to make the product here,” he said. “And they have a lot of other alternatives.”
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM | 272 Comments
  • KOS

    Kosmos Energy -3% on news of secondary offering, share repurchase

    • Kosmos Energy (NYSE:KOS) -2.9% after-hours as Warburg Pincus agrees to sell 15M common shares in a secondary public offering, with an underwriter's option to purchase up to an additional 2.25M shares; KOS will not receive any proceeds from the sale.
    • In addition, KOS agrees to repurchase 35M of its common shares from Warburg Pincus in a separate, privately negotiated repurchase agreement at a price equal to what the selling shareholder will receive from its sale of common stock to the underwriter.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:21 PM
  • ENTA

    Enanta Pharma FQ4 top line down 12%; earnings down 25%; shares down 1% after hours

    • Enanta Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ENTA) fiscal Q4 results ($M): Revenue: 67.2 (-11.5%). FQ4 2017 revenue included a $65M milestone payment triggered by approval of MAVYRET/MAVIRET in the U.S. and EU.
    • Revenue of $67.2M was all royalties, up over five-fold from a year ago (from MAVYRET/MAVIRET sales).
    • Net income: 27.4 (-24.9%); EPS: 1.30 (-30.1%).
    • Fiscal 2019 guidance: R&D expense: $135M - 155M; G&A expense: $27M - 33M.
    • Shares are down 1% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM
  • SCG

    SCANA upgraded to Hold from Sell at Williams after lawsuit settlement

    • SCANA (SCG +5.7%) is upgraded to Hold from Sell with a $49 price target, raised from $30, at Williams Capital, which admits its bearish investment thesis on the company since the Dominion merger news was based on the belief that as announced the terms of the deal were insufficient to get approval.
    • But it appears state political objectives have changed in view of the company's weekend settlement agreement in the South Carolina electric customer class action.
    • Williams now says the settlement, Dominion's recently revised rate plan and the endorsement by the South Carolina House Speaker of Dominion's revised rate plan, leads it to believe that the probability that the Dominion merger will be approved by the state Public Service Commission has increased to the extent that a Sell rating on the stock is no longer warranted.
    • Source: Briefing.com
     
     
     
     
    | 3:56 PM | 2 Comments
  • BAC

    Financials rally, but still down YTD

    • Financial stocks start the post-Thanksgiving week strong, with the Financial Select SPDR ETF (NYSEARCA:XLF) up 2.2% in late trading; but in the past three months it's declined 5.6% and YTD -4.7%.
    • The U.S. megabanks are all up at least 2%: Bank of America (BAC +2.5%), Citigroup (C +3.5%), JPMorgan (JPM +2.6%), Wells Fargo (WFC +2.5%), Goldman Sachs (GS +2.8%), and Morgan Stanley (MS +3.1%).
    • Regional banks are also making a strong showing with SunTrust Banks (STI +3.3%), CIT Group (CIT +3.2%), New York Community Bancorp (NYCB +3.1%), and Axos Financial (AX +3.2%) leading.
    • In Europe, Deutsche Bank (DB +5.1%) leads, with U.K. banks HSBC Holdings (HSBC +3.5%), Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS +3.1%), and Barclays (BCS +2.8%) also on the upswing.
    • Credit-card companies American Express (AXP +3.6%), Alliance Data Systems (ADS +3.1%), and Discover Financial Services (DFS +3.3%) make strong gains.
    • Auto finance firms Ally Financial (ALLY +3.5%) and Santander Consumer USA (SC +3.4%) advance.
    • Another healthy performer late Monday is life insurers: Brighthouse Financial (BHF +3.9%), Aegon (AEG +2.8%), MetLife (MET +2.5%), and Manulife Financial (MFC +2.4%).
    • Previously: Stocks at session highs late in session (Nov. 26)
    • ETFs: XLF, FAS, FAZ, VFH, UYG, FNCL, IYF, BTO, IYG, RYF, FXO, SEF-OLD, FINU, FINZ, JHMF
     
     
     
     
    | 3:45 PM | 36 Comments
  • PCG

    California fire relief for PG&E may not include inverse condemnation fix

    • PG&E (PCG +5.1%) says its gas and electric crews continue with restoration work in areas impacted by the Camp Fire, as California officials say the state's deadliest-ever fire is now 100% contained.
    • Meanwhile, Bloomberg reports the utility may soon get help from state lawmakers, but not the help it most wants.
    • A state lawmaker soon plans to introduce a bill that would give PG&E a way to pay off billions of dollars in potential liabilities it faces from the Camp Fire, but lawmakers appear unlikely to give PG&E and the state’s other utilities a change to rules that automatically hold the companies responsible for any fire damage tied to their equipment, according to the report.
    • State Assemblyman Chris Holden, who plans to introduce the measure for 2018 fires, tells Bloomberg he is unconvinced legislators need to review the inverse condemnation rule since they have earlier passed a package that addresses fires starting next year.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:39 PM | 9 Comments
  • IPCI

    FDA OKs Intellipharmaceutics' generic Effexor; shares up 14%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Intellipharmaceutics (IPCI +13.5%) is up on more than a 7x surge in volume in response to the FDA nod for its generic version of Pfizer's (PFE +0.6%) antidepressant Effexor (venlafaxine HCl).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:27 PM | 5 Comments

  • Stocks at session highs late in session

    • Just a bit more than 30 minutes before the close, the Nasdaq has moved to a 1.8% advance, with the S&P 500 up 1.4%, and DJIA ahead 1.3%.
    • Oil's bouncing along with stocks, up 2.25% to $51.56 per barrel.
    • The 10-year Treasury yield is higher by 2.5 basis points to 3.065%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM | 1 Comment
  • GM

    Trump weighs in on GM's plans

    • President Trump says he talked to General Motors (GM +5.6%) CEO Mary Barra about the company's plans to cut production in North America last night ahead of the formal announcement.
    • While Trump wants GM's production in Ohio to be replaced, Barra said earlier today that the company is looking to make itself lean and agile to get in front and lead in autonomous and electric vehicles.
    • Trump would also like to see GM stop producing cars in China, a sentiment also echoed today by the United Auto Workers.
    • GM and Ford have been making their production decisions in reaction to supply and demand issues for the most part.
    • Previously: Meet the new GM (Nov. 26)
    • Previously: GM takes auto sector for a ride higher (Nov. 26)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:22 PM | 127 Comments
  • ANY

    SPWR, JKS and QTM among notable tech movers

    • Gainers: Safe-T Group (NASDAQ:SFET) +50%. Sphere 3D (NASDAQ:ANY) +33%. SunPower Corporation (NASDAQ:SPWR) +17%. Quantum Corporation (NYSE:QTM-OLD) +16%. JinkoSolar Holding (NYSE:JKS) +15%.
    • Losers: FTE Networks (NYSEMKT:FTNW) -12%. 21Vianet Group (NASDAQ:VNET) -9%. Plantronics (NYSE:PLT) -9%. The9 Limited (NASDAQ:NCTY) -9%. Identiv (NASDAQ:INVE) -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:02 PM | 8 Comments
  • GE

    GE slides again as analyst flags new warning sign for finance arm

    • General Electric (GE -1.9%) shares are on track to suffer their 20th decline over the past 23 sessions after Gordon Haskett analyst John Inch pointed out that the Chapter 11 bankruptcy of helicopter lessor Waypoint Leasing could spell trouble for GE Capital.
    • GE acquired aircraft operating lease company Milestone Aviation for $1.8B in 2014, and - assuming no writedown since then of goodwill - the business would account for nearly 75% of GE Capital’s reported goodwill of $984M as of Q3, Inch says, and "a writedown of its Milestone assets could prove highly material to GE Capital."
    • One bit of good news for GE: Its bonds have rebounded sharply in recent days, as GE Capital's frequently traded bonds due 2035 have rallied 6% since Nov. 21 to $0.8232 on the dollar and the cost of protecting against a default on GE bonds for five years through credit default swaps, which falls as investor confidence rises, has declined 26% in recent days to $197K annually.
    • Bond prices have recovered at least in part because selling eased from large institutions and funds with restrictions on holding junk-rated debt, which unloaded billions of dollars of securities in mid-November, WSJ reports.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:51 PM | 101 Comments
  • BP

    Reuters: Venezuela rejected BP bid to buy Total's stake in gas block

    • Venezuela’s oil ministry last month turned down a proposal by BP (BP +1.7%) to buy Total's (TOT +1.3%) 49% stake in a promising but inactive natural gas project along the maritime border with Trinidad and Tobago, Reuters reports; Equinor (EQNR +0.9%) owns the other 51%.
    • The oil ministry reportedly told the parties the area’s reserves needed to be re-estimated, an argument it has used to reject other deals.
    • BP owns the rights to the Trinidad side of the gas play and could have used the production from the neighboring area to feed its growing operations on the island, according to the report.
    • Venezuela’s mostly undeveloped gas reserves totaled 225T cf at the end of 2017, compared with Trinidad’s 9.2T cf.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:27 PM | 8 Comments
  • MNK

    Bearish Citron tweets pressure Mallinckrodt, down 11%

    • Mallinckrodt (MNK -10.5%) is down on more than double normal volume in apparent response to bearish tweets from Citron Research who questions the efficacy of top seller Acthar Gel.
    • Citron says a full report is on the way.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:12 PM | 22 Comments
  • SDPI

    Superior Drilling Products and Transmontaigne Partners among Energy/Materials gainers; Cloud Peak Energy and Americas Silver among losers

    • Gainers: Superior Drilling Products (NYSEMKT:SDPI) +20%. Transmontaigne Partners (NYSE:TLP) +13%. Legacy Reserves (NASDAQ:LGCY) +12%. VAALCO Energy (NYSE:EGY) +10%. Amyris (NASDAQ:AMRS) +10%.
    • Losers: Cloud Peak Energy (NYSE:CLD) -20%. Americas Silver (NYSEMKT:USAS) -9%. Sanchez Midstream Partners (NYSEMKT:SNMP) -9%. Dawson Geophysical (NASDAQ:DWSN) -9%. U.S. Silica Holdings (NYSE:SLCA) -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM | 5 Comments
  • ARRS

    Jefferies upgrades CommScope, expects successful Arris deal

    • Arris (ARRS +0.9%) is trailer broader tech market gains after a downgrade to Hold at Jefferies, which doesn't think it's likely that the company will see a competing bid for its buyout by CommScope (COMM +2.4%).
    • Accordingly, Jefferies cut its price target to the deal price: $31.75, about 2.4% upside from current pricing.
    • The firm has meanwhile upgraded CommScope to Buy, noting "near-trough valuations, terrible investor sentiment, and a pending de-leveraging story"; a likely sale of its set-top business could help reduce the debt load (with proceeds it expects around $500M in a distressed sale) and enhance multiples and growth rates, it says. (h/t Bloomberg)
    • Its price target on CommScope is $28.50, implying 58% upside.
    • Previously: Goldman takes Sell sign off Arris after earnings, buyout deal (Nov. 08 2018)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:52 PM | 3 Comments
  • GOOGL

    Baird sees Alphabet cloud M&A

    • Baird thinks Alphabet (GOOGL, GOOG) should make a big M&A move to boost its Google Cloud platform, which ranks fourth behind Amazon, Microsoft and Alibaba with 3% cloud computing market share.
    • "As Google seeks to carve out greater share in the expanding enterprise Cloud Services market, we believe the company should embark on a more-aggressive 'shopping spree' to improve commercialization with the help of enterprise-scale 'killer apps' and a better-developed sales and support organization," advises the Baird team.
    • Baird lists Workday (WDAY +3.4%), Atlassian (TEAM +3.3%), Zendesk (ZEN +1.7%), LogMeIn (LOGM +1%), ServiceNow (NOW +3.9%), Salesforce.com (CRM +3.1%), Tableau Software (DATA +3.2%) and Box (BOX +1.9%), as potential Alphabet targets.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:24 PM | 25 Comments
  • CBS

    Report: Zelnick could be expensive choice to helm CBS/Viacom

    • More smoke around the prospect of Take-Two (TTWO +2.9%) chief Strauss Zelnick taking over a potentially combined CBS and Viacom (VIA, VIAB) -- though that deal would come at a substantial price.
    • The two companies each have heads in place, and they have substantial cash guarantees in case of a change in ownership.
    • Bob Bakish, currently head of Viacom, stands to receive $50M, and interim CBS boss Joe Ianniello could receive $70M, in case of a change in ownership where they don't end up as the chosen leader, the New York Post reports.
    • CBS is currently searching for a permanent CEO; that search is expected to end in the middle of the first quarter, after which merger talks are expected to begin, according to the report.
    • Previously: Report: CBS/Viacom could come in three months; Take-Two too? (Nov. 19 2018)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM | 3 Comments
  • SVBI

    Severn Bancorp leads financial gainers; Sachem Capital and Marine Petroleum Trust among losers

    • Gainers: Severn Bancorp (NASDAQ:SVBI) +10%. CPI Card Group (NASDAQ:PMTS) +10%. China Internet Nationwide Financial Services (NASDAQ:CIFS) +8%. Mr. Cooper Group (NASDAQ:COOP) +5%. LendingTree (NASDAQ:TREE) +5%.
    • Losers: Innovative Industrial Properties (NYSE:IIPR) -13%. Marine Petroleum Trust (NASDAQ:MARPS) -10%. Banco Santander (NYSE:BSMX) -8%. CNFinance Holdings (NYSE:CNF) -7%. Sachem Capital (NYSEMKT:SACH) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:04 PM | 1 Comment
  • CPG

    Crescent Point Energy urgently needs new leadership, Cation Capital says

    • Crescent Point Energy (CPG +3.1%) is higher after shareholder Cation Capital takes another swing at the company, warning it "reserves every right to bring about change for the benefit of all shareholders" if CPG cannot "effect positive change, including installing independent leadership to lead a formal value maximization process."
    • Cation commented on "ongoing value erosion" of CPG's share price due to the "clear failure of leadership and governance within the company."
    • Cation says it has "made repeated, good faith efforts to engage constructively with the company... In response, the company has taken clearly ineffective half measures."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM | 72 Comments
  • RSLS

    ReShape shares halted pending news; shares up 7%

    • Nasdaq has suspended trading in ReShape Lifesciences (OTC:RSLS +7.2%) pending the release of news.
    • Update: In a direct offering, the company intends to sell 8M common shares and warrants to purchase up to 8M shares at $1.25 at a combined price of $1.25 per share and warrant.
    • Trading will resume at 1:30 pm ET.
    • Update: Approaching 2:00 pm ET shares are exchanging hands at $1.05, down 16%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM | 2 Comments
  • TYME

    Tyme Tech up 16% ahead of data readout on SM-88 in pancreatic cancer

    • Thinly traded micro cap Tyme Technologies (TYME +15.8%) is up on modestly higher volume on the heels of its announcement that preliminary data from a Phase 2 clinical trial evaluating lead candidate SM-88 in patients with pancreatic cancer will be presented at the Gastrointestinal Cancers Symposium in San Francisco on January 18, 2019.
    • Results from an earlier 10-subject study in treatment-resistant pancreatic cancer showed a 30% response rate.
    • SM-88 is a combination therapy that uses a proprietary dysfunctional tyrosine derivative to interrupt the metabolic processes of cancer cells, breaking down their defenses and making them vulnerable to oxidative stress and death.
    • Previously: Tyme Tech's lead candidate shows positive effect in early-stage pancreatic cancer study; shares ahead 2% (Jan. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM
  • GE

    Fixing GE's debt pile 'critical' to corporate America, Nomura analyst says

    • How General Electric (GE -3.9%) resolves its debt problem will be "critical" to the wider investment grade market, because it is "such a massive pile of the corporate credit market and the IG market," Nomura's Bob Janjuah tells CNBC.
    • Despite decent cash levels on an aggregate basis,"if you break it down, you realize that the vast bulk of that cash holding is by about eight companies and that most of corporate U.S. is actually more levered than it has ever been," Janjuah says.
    • Not everyone is predicting gloom for the corporate credit market: Steven Oh, global head of credit and fixed income at PineBridge Investments, considers GE an "idiosyncratic problem" brought about by poor management that does not represent broader market conditions across credit.
    • In most cases, high debt is an intentional part of boardroom strategy and cash flows at many U.S. firms remains in positive territory, Oh says; "in the near-term, they have the ability to shore up their position to limit that downside should there be an economic downturn."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM | 64 Comments
  • ANY

    Microcaps mostly among midday movers

    • Gainers: Safe-T Group (NASDAQ:SFET) +47%. Sphere 3D (NASDAQ:ANY) +32%. Quantum (NYSE:QTM-OLD) +19%. Adial Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ADIL) +17%. InVivo Therapeutics Holdings (NASDAQ:NVIV) +16%. Tyme Technologies (NASDAQ:TYME) +16%. The Dixie Group (NASDAQ:DXYN) +15%. Superior Drilling Products (NYSEMKT:SDPI) +15%. SunPower (NASDAQ:SPWR) +14%. Transmontaigne Partners (NYSE:TLP) +13%.
    • Losers: Zafgen (NASDAQ:ZFGN) -43%. Cloud Peak Energy (NYSE:CLD) -22%. Tenax Therapeutics (NASDAQ:TENX) -20%. Overstock.com (NASDAQ:OSTK) -17%. Gamida Cell (NASDAQ:GMDA) -16%. Orchids Paper Products Company (NYSEMKT:TIS) -16%. Innovative Industrial Properties (NYSE:IIPR) -15%. Equillium (NASDAQ:EQ) -13%. Curis (NASDAQ:CRIS) -12%. Genprex (NASDAQ:GNPX) -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:42 PM | 9 Comments
  • ANY

    Sphere 3D adds to rally, up 32%

    • Nano cap Sphere 3D (ANY +31.8%) is up more than a 10x surge in volume. Shares have rallied almost five-fold since touching $1.52 on November 8. Several weeks ago, it executed a 1:8 reverse stock split and closed its divestiture of Overland Storage.
    • On November 19, it disclosed the receipt of a noncompliance notice from Nasdaq related to minimum stockholders equity and a new CEO.
    • At the end of Q3, it had $2.1M in cash and equivalents while operations consumed $4.2M across the first three quarters.
    • Previously: Sphere 3D receives Nasdaq letter, changes CEO (Nov. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:31 PM | 1 Comment
  • XOM

    Oil surges following last week's steep selloff that many felt was overdone

    • Today’s surge in crude oil prices is "probably a reaction to Friday’s selloff" which investors may see as "too exaggerated," but the oil market remains little changed from a "fundamental perspective," says UBS Wealth Management analyst Giovanni Staunovo.
    • Goldman Sachs also says the recent slide in oil and other commodities was overdone and suggests investors now take long positions, and Cantor Fitzgerald thinks the recent weakness "seems dramatic given the lack of actual catalysts - it seems to have been driven by a wider impending sense of doom amidst weak equities, geopolitics, subsequent softening demand and increasing supply."
    • "It would not be surprising to see some fierce short-covering taking place in the run up to the OPEC+ meeting" at the end of next week, says PVM Oil Associates analyst Tamas Varga.
